segment.source: WinPE: Store or split images to deploy Windows using a single USB key
segment.target: WinPE: Store or split images to deploy Windows using a single USB key

segment.source: WinPE: Store or split images to deploy Windows using a single USB key
segment.target: WinPE: Store or split images to deploy Windows using a single USB key

segment.source: WinPE: Store or split images to deploy Windows using a single USB key
segment.target: WinPE: Store or split images to deploy Windows using a single USB key

segment.source: How can you deploy Windows to PCs with just one USB port?
segment.target: How can you deploy Windows to PCs with just one USB port?

segment.source: The default Windows Preinstallation Environment (WinPE) drive format, FAT32, is used to boot UEFI-based PCs, but that's too small to store most Windows images:
segment.target: The default Windows Preinstallation Environment (WinPE) drive format, FAT32, is used to boot UEFI-based PCs, but that's too small to store most Windows images:

segment.source: FAT32 has a maximum file size of 4GB in size.
segment.target: FAT32 has a maximum file size of 4GB in size.

segment.source: Most customized Windows images are over 4GB.
segment.target: Most customized Windows images are over 4GB.

segment.source: FAT32 has a maximum partition size of 32GB.
segment.target: FAT32 has a maximum partition size of 32GB.

segment.source: Some Windows images are larger than 32GB.
segment.target: Some Windows images are larger than 32GB.

segment.source: (You can still use a 64GB or 128GB USB key, but you have to format it to use only uses 32GB of its space.)
segment.target: (You can still use a 64GB or 128GB USB key, but you have to format it to use only uses 32GB of its space.)

segment.source: Here's a few ways around these limitations:
segment.target: Here's a few ways around these limitations:

segment.source: Option 1: Store the image on a separate USB drive
segment.target: Option 1: Store the image on a separate USB drive

segment.source: Even if your PC only has one USB port, you can still deploy Windows using two separate USB keys.
segment.target: Even if your PC only has one USB port, you can still deploy Windows using two separate USB keys.

segment.source: Boot to WinPE.
segment.target: Boot to WinPE.

segment.source: Remove the WinPE drive.
segment.target: Remove the WinPE drive.

segment.source: (After booting, WinPE runs in memory.)
segment.target: (After booting, WinPE runs in memory.)

segment.source: Plug in a separate storage drive with your image and apply it to the device.
segment.target: Plug in a separate storage drive with your image and apply it to the device.

segment.source: Option 2: Store the image on a network location
segment.target: Option 2: Store the image on a network location

segment.source: Copy the image to a server on your network, for example, servershareinstall.wim
segment.target: Copy the image to a server on your network, for example, servershareinstall.wim

segment.source: Boot to WinPE.
segment.target: Boot to WinPE.

segment.source: Connect a network drive using a drive letter, for example, N.
segment.target: Connect a network drive using a drive letter, for example, N.

segment.source: Apply the image from the network.
segment.target: Apply the image from the network.

segment.source: Option 3: Split the image
segment.target: Option 3: Split the image

segment.source: Limitations:
segment.target: Limitations:

segment.source: Windows Setup doesn't support installing from a split .wim file for Windows 10.You cannot modify a split .wim file.
segment.target: Windows Setup doesn't support installing from a split .wim file for Windows 10.You cannot modify a split .wim file.

segment.source: You can't modify a split .wim file.
segment.target: You can't modify a split .wim file.

segment.source: To use a 64GB or 128GB key, format it to only use 32GB of space.
segment.target: To use a 64GB or 128GB key, format it to only use 32GB of space.

segment.source: For images larger than 32GB, you'd need a second USB key anyway because of the FAT32 partition size limitation.
segment.target: For images larger than 32GB, you'd need a second USB key anyway because of the FAT32 partition size limitation.

segment.source: From your technician PC, create your WinPE key.
segment.target: From your technician PC, create your WinPE key.

segment.source: See WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive.
segment.target: See WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive.

segment.source: Open the Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment as an adminstrator.
segment.target: Open the Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment as an adminstrator.

segment.source: Split the Windows image into files smaller than 4GB each:
segment.target: Split the Windows image into files smaller than 4GB each:

segment.source: where:
segment.target: where:

segment.source: is the name and the location of the image file that you want to split.
segment.target: is the name and the location of the image file that you want to split.

segment.source: is the destination name and the location for the split .wim files.
segment.target: is the destination name and the location for the split .wim files.

segment.source: is the maximum size in MB for each of the split .wim files to be created.
segment.target: is the maximum size in MB for each of the split .wim files to be created.

segment.source: In this example, the /split option creates an install.swm file, an install2.swm file, an install3.swm file, and so on, in the D:Images directory.
segment.target: In this example, the /split option creates an install.swm file, an install2.swm file, an install3.swm file, and so on, in the D:Images directory.

segment.source: Copy the files to the WinPE key.
segment.target: Copy the files to the WinPE key.

segment.source: On the destination PC, boot to WinPE, and then apply an image using DISM /Apply-Image /SWMFile command.
segment.target: On the destination PC, boot to WinPE, and then apply an image using DISM /Apply-Image /SWMFile command.

segment.source: Option 4: Create a multiple partition USB drive (Windows to Go or other storage drive)
segment.target: Option 4: Create a multiple partition USB drive (Windows to Go or other storage drive)

segment.source: Most flash drives report themselves as removable drives, but to create multiple partitions on a USB drive the drive must report itself as a fixed (non-removable) drive.
segment.target: Most flash drives report themselves as removable drives, but to create multiple partitions on a USB drive the drive must report itself as a fixed (non-removable) drive.

segment.source: If you have access to a Windows to Go (WTG) certified drive you can use it, because WTG drives report as fixed.
segment.target: If you have access to a Windows to Go (WTG) certified drive you can use it, because WTG drives report as fixed.

segment.source: Some USB external hard drives also report themselves as fixed.
segment.target: Some USB external hard drives also report themselves as fixed.

segment.source: Verify if the drive is reporting itself as fixed or removable
segment.target: Verify if the drive is reporting itself as fixed or removable

segment.source: Plug in the drive.
segment.target: Plug in the drive.

segment.source: Right-click Start, select Disk Management.
segment.target: Right-click Start, select Disk Management.

segment.source: In the left pane on the bottom of the screen, the drive will say Basic instead of Removable.
segment.target: In the left pane on the bottom of the screen, the drive will say Basic instead of Removable.

segment.source: Create a drive with multiple partitions
segment.target: Create a drive with multiple partitions

segment.source: Start the Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment as an administrator.
segment.target: Start the Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment as an administrator.

segment.source: Type diskpart and press Enter.
segment.target: Type diskpart and press Enter.

segment.source: Use Diskpart to reformat the drive and create two new partitions for WinPE and for your images:
segment.target: Use Diskpart to reformat the drive and create two new partitions for WinPE and for your images:

segment.source: Copy the WinPE files to the WinPE partition:
segment.target: Copy the WinPE files to the WinPE partition:

segment.source: Copy the Windows image file to the Images partition:
segment.target: Copy the Windows image file to the Images partition:

segment.target: Split a Windows image file (.wim) for FAT32 media or to span across multiple DVDs
